title: Parametric Curves & Vector Functions
description: Learn how to understand, visualize, and work with parametric curves and their tangent vectors.

calc2_week1_review.description: A detailed review of parametric curves, opposite directions, derivatives, tangent lines, and worked examples.

slides.title: What is a Parametric Curve?
slides.content: A parametric curve expresses coordinates as functions of a parameter t. This allows us to describe motion along a curve in space.
slides.equation: r(t) = (x(t), y(t)) \\text{ or } r(t) = (x(t), y(t), z(t))

slides.title: Worked Example: Parametric Curve
slides.content: Example: r(t) = (t, e^t) describes an exponential curve. At t = 0, point is (0,1). At t = 1, point is (1, e). This shows exponential growth.

slides.title: Opposite Directions on the Same Curve
slides.content: Two parameterizations can define the same curve in opposite directions. Example: r(t) = (t, e^t) moves forward; c(s) = (1 - s, e^(1 - s)) moves backward.

slides.title: Finding Derivatives of Parametric Curves
slides.content: The derivative r'(t) shows the direction and speed of movement at each point — also called the velocity vector.

slides.title: Worked Example: Derivative and Tangent Vector
slides.content: Example: r(t) = (t^2, sin t, e^t). Then r'(t) = (2t, cos t, e^t). At t = 1: r'(1) = (2, cos(1), e). Draw this tangent vector at point r(1).

slides.title: Recognizing Common Curve Types
slides.content: Hyperbolic functions (sinh, cosh) create hyperbolic shapes; trigonometric functions (sin, cos) form circles and spirals.
slides.equation: r(t) = (\\sinh t, \\cosh t) \\text{ or } r(t) = (\\cos t, \\sin t)

slides.title: Quick Recap
slides.content: Remember: 1) Identify the curve type. 2) Compute derivatives. 3) Draw tangent vectors. 4) Recognize opposite directions. 5) Label clearly.

calc2_week1_level1.description: Test your understanding of parametric curves and tangent vectors.

questions.question: What is the derivative of r(t) = (t², sin t, e^t)?
At t = 1, what does the tangent vector to r(t) = (t, e^t) represent?
options: The direction and speed of motion at that point
The point where the curve crosses the x-axis
The second derivative of the function
questions.correctAnswer: The direction and speed of motion at that point
